BC-BKN-SUNS-McDYESS-AZR 
ROLL  OF THE 'DYESS  
 SUNS MAY LOSE BET THEY COULD KEEP STAR 

   (For use by N.Y. Times News Service clients)  
 By BOB YOUNG  
 c.1999 The Arizona Republic  

   With the start of training camp looming early next week, the
Suns and many of the NBA's other 28 teams can do nothing but wait
patiently while Phoenix free agent star Antonio McDyess makes up
his mind.

   It appears that McDyess will decide between the Suns and his old
club, the Denver Nuggets. The Nuggets might have the edge, even
though the Suns can pay more.

   The Houston Rockets still are interested but apparently are
zeroing in on Chicago Bulls free agent Scottie Pippen. Orlando
apparently has tried to enter the McDyess sweepstakes, and Chicago
Bulls General Manager Jerry Krause is making a strong drive for
him.

   McDyess, Pippen and Minnesota free agent Tom Gugliotta are the
most attractive players on the market, and until their decisions
are made, very little else can fall into place.

   The Suns have not given McDyess any kind of deadline, said one
of McDyess' agents, James Bryant.

   ``I think everyone wants to know what's going on as soon as
possible,'' Bryant said. ``But there haven't been any demands. We
don't know when Antonio is going to make a decision. We feel like
it's all starting to crystallize. I'd expect one pretty soon.''

   The NBA deal is expected to be finalized Monday or Tuesday,
which will bring a wave of free agent signings.

   The Suns would like an answer as quickly as possible, Bryant
said, to determine where they go next if McDyess leaves. And those
options may be drying up.

   League sources said Thursday that Gugliotta has come to terms
with the Timberwolves. Minnesota still could sign him and make a
trade, but either way, the Suns apparently are out of the picture.

   So where do they go if Gugliotta is off the board and McDyess is
holding a news conference in Denver?

   Because of the new collective bargaining rules, few options
remain. League sources said that Chicago center Luc Longley is
ready to make a deal with Phoenix.

   The Suns probably would make an offer to their own free agent
forward, Clifford Robinson, who has had an offer from the Detroit
Pistons.

   Then the Suns still could go after another, less expensive free
agent such as Miami's Brent Barry, whom the club wanted to draft in
1995.

   Sign-and-trade scenarios are possible, but most teams probably
would want the Suns' first-round draft pick obtained from Dallas
last summer in the trade that sent Steve Nash to the Mavericks. The
Suns might be better off holding on to that chip.

   The Suns gambled in October 1997 when they traded guard Wesley
Person, forward Tony Dumas and four draft picks _ two first- and
two second-round selections _ in a three-team deal with Cleveland
and Denver, to get the 6-foot-10, 220-pound McDyess.

   The risk was that the club might not be able to re-sign McDyess
when he became a free agent at the end of the season.

   Why would McDyess consider the Nuggets, a team that won 11 games
last season?

   First, the Nuggets fired General Manager Allan Bristow, who
traded McDyess and said he wasn't worth a $100 million contract.
McDyess said last season that he would not consider playing in
Denver again if Bristow were there. He was replaced by Dan Issel,
whom McDyess likes.

   Second, the Nuggets traded for Nick Van Exel. McDyess and Van
Exel have become friends, and there is speculation that he will
agree to go to Denver if the Nuggets give Van Exel a new deal next
summer when his contract is up. By the way, they have the same
agents.

   Third, McDyess is a small-town guy who still feels connected
with some of his friends in Denver and would feel comfortable with
Van Exel around. His two closest friends with the Suns were Nash,
who was traded, and John ``Hot Rod'' Williams, who won't be
re-signed.

   Finally, it's possible McDyess never wanted to leave the Nuggets
in the first place. He fired his last agent, Arn Tellem, and hired
Bryant and Tony Dutt, reportedly because Tellem forced a trade from
Denver by demanding a $100 million contract from the Nuggets.
Tellem apparently didn't tell McDyess what the Nuggets had on the
table.

   Bryant said McDyess likes the Phoenix organization, Coach Danny
Ainge and his teammates with the Suns, who apparently have been
letting him know they want him back.

   ``It's just a different situation with these new rules,'' Bryant
said. ``It's almost like choosing a college now. The money is about
the same wherever he goes. You have to consider a lot more factors,
like the style of play, the makeup of the team, how you fit into
the plan, how competitive the team has a chance to be. There is a
lot to consider.''

   McDyess could not be reached for comment. A friend who is
screening calls made to McDyess' home and cellular numbers said
McDyess will not speak with reporters until he has made his
decision.

   If the Suns renounce the rights to McDyess, they will be about
$10.7 million below the salary cap if they keep their five contract
players and do not renounce Robinson, Rex Chapman and Marko Milic.

   Robinson reportedly has been offered a contract by the Detroit
Pistons, but if McDyess leaves, the Suns likely would offer him
some of their available cap space to keep him in Phoenix.

   Still, McDyess would be a huge loss.

   McDyess was arguably the Suns' best player over the last month
of the 1997-98 season and during a first-round playoff loss to the
San Antonio Spurs.

   During April, in which the Suns were 8-1, he averaged 19.3
points, 7.1 rebounds, 2.1 blocked shots and 1.89 steals, and shot
62.2 percent.

   For the season, he averaged 15.1 points and 7.6 rebounds and
joined Alvan Adams and Garfield Heard as the only Suns to have at
least 100 blocked shots and 100 steals in a season.
